title: R41768
content: The federal parity law aims to ensure that coverage terms for mental health and substance use disorder services are no more restrictive than those for medical and surgical services. It consists of two laws: the Mental Health Parity Act of 1996 and the Paul Wellstone and Pete Domenici Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008. These laws require certain coverage terms to be equal between mental health services and medical services. The federal mental health parity requirements ensure that coverage terms for mental health and substance use disorder services are on par with medical and surgical services. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 did not modify these specific coverage terms. The ACA did not change federal mental health parity requirements, which ensure equal coverage for mental health and substance use disorder services compared to medical and surgical services. Parity law applies to insurers covering these services and certain plan types, including large fully insured and self-insured plans, Medicaid managed care plans, and CHIP plans. The ACA expands federal mental health parity requirements to include Qualified Health Plans (QHPs), individual market plans, and Medicaid benchmark plans. The ACA expands federal mental health parity requirements to include three types of plans: Qualified Health Plans (QHPs) offered through Exchanges, plans in the individual market, and Medicaid benchmark and benchmark-equivalent plans. QHPs must comply with federal parity law to the same extent as other health insurance issuers and group health plans. The law aims to reduce disparities in coverage terms between mental health services and medical services. Federal parity law aims to address disparities in coverage terms for mental health and substance use disorder services compared to medical and surgical services. While the law does not mandate coverage for mental health and substance use disorder services, it requires parity with medical and surgical services if they are covered, known as a mandated offering parity approach. The ACA did not change the mandated offering parity approach of federal parity law, which requires parity with medical and surgical services if mental health and substance use disorder services are covered. However, the ACA introduced broader changes that include requirements for the coverage of mental health and substance use disorder services. The ACA mandates that QHPs, new plans in the small and individual markets, and Medicaid benchmark plans offer either the EHBP or EHB. Medicaid benchmark plans must cover the EHB. The ACA requires QHPs, new plans in the small and individual markets, and Medicaid benchmark plans to include coverage of the Essential Health Benefits (EHB) by January 1, 2014.
